title: Gold Mafia | Al Jazeera documentary on alleged gold trading in Zimbabwe
description:
Part one of a documentary by Al Jazeera called Gold Mafia that focuses on Zimbabwe has shocked many. The news network has suggested there are more revelations to come. The documentary shows the Zimbabwean government is using gold smugglers to evade western sanctions. The gold mafia is licenced to buy gold from small producers that would otherwise have been smuggled out of the country. The mafia then exports the gold to Dubai. 

All the while money laundering is going on.The dirty money of criminals comes back to Zimbabwe as legitimate revenue from gold. Back in Dubai money from the gold sales is transferred into bank accounts and seems to be legitimate. There is also evidence showing that suggests the rhenium president is condoning his own officials facilitating laundering, land that people are charged to see the president. 

GUESTS | Hopewell Chin'ono, Zimbabwe, investigative journalist. Thompson Chengeta, associate professor of international human rights law. UK Thembisa Fakude, Africa Asia Dialogues Director Joburg.  

For more news, visit sabcnews.com and #SABCNews on all Social Media platforms.

title: Global National: March 20, 2020 | Canada surpasses 1,000 cases of COVID-19
description:
The federal government is calling on Canada's manufacturing companies to join the fight against COVID-19 by ramping up production of vital supplies, like medical supplies. But as Mike Armstrong reports, things aren't so rosy for a different industry.

Meanwhile, the virus has led to the unemployment of thousands of Canadians, and the federal government is racing to mitigate the damage of what may be the worst economic downturn in the country's history. David Akin reports on how much the federal government’s potential support package could be worth.

The U.S. is ramping up its war against COVID-19 by closing its borders with Canada and Mexico to non-essential travel, while lockdowns are in effect in both California and New York. But what about a nationwide lockdown? And what would U.S. President Donald Trump say to Americans who are scared? Jackson Proskow has Trump's reaction to both of those questions.

The British government is also taking drastic measures to help citizens who can't work due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Redmond Shannon explains what's being promised.

Scores of Canadians working and living abroad are trying in vain to return home, but travel restrictions and bans over COVID-19 have them fearing they'll be stranded indefinitely. Ross Lord has the calls for help from Canadians stuck in Peru.

There's a worldwide outpour of gratitude for health care workers, who are putting themselves at risk while treating a surge of patients during the COVID-19 pandemic. Eric Sorensen explains how their difficult work is being honoured.


For more info, please go to https://globalnews.ca/news/6710672/canada-coronavirus-1000-cases/

title: Global National: Feb. 3, 2023 | What suspected Chinese spy balloon means for diplomacy with China
description:
In our top story: The Pentagon is tracking a Chinese surveillance balloon over the U.S. right now. It flew through Canadian airspace and Global News has learned pilots were warned by air traffic controllers to be on the lookout for an untethered balloon. Jackson Proskow reports on how the U.S. is responding.

Tensions between Canada and China are also rising with the balloon having passed over Canada this week. Chief political correspondent David Akin has more on what the federal government has been saying.

These types of balloons are not new. In fact, similar tactics have been used for espionage in the early days of the Cold War. Eric Sorensen takes a look at the balloon and explores why old-fashioned technology is being used in the age of sophisticated satellites.

There are new concerns over the worldwide spread of another virus: avian flu. For more than a year, there's been a significant uptick in cases among wild birds and farmed poultry. Now, there's new evidence the illness is spreading among other mammals. Heather Yourex-West reports.

European Union leaders met with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy in Kyiv on Friday. As Redmond Shannon reports, he once again pled for stronger weapons as the country approaches one year in Russia's war.

And finally, NASA is taking the threat of an asteroid hitting the Earth seriously and working on a planetary defence program for that very reason. Global's Su-Ling reports on the recent big step it took towards its protection program.

For more info, please go to https://globalnews.ca/news/9457135/chinese-spy-balloon-us-airpsace/

title: Global National: March 2, 2020 | Coronavirus death toll rises in the U.S.
description:
The number of confirmed cases of COVID-19 is rising in the U.S., while the number of deaths related to the outbreak rises to six - all in Washington state. Abigail Bimman reports on the growing concern and frustrations with the U.S. government's outbreak response.

Meanwhile, Robin Gill explains how prepared Canadian health officials are if a wider outbreak of COVID-19 takes shape here. Plus, Crystal Goomansingh provides new updates as the coronavirus intensifies in Iran, South Korea, and Italy.
 
Sarah MacDonald reports on the reaction to the new territory deal between Wet'suwet'en hereditary chiefs and the federal government, even though it won't apply to the Coastal GasLink pipeline. Plus, Mike Armstrong reports on a new rail line blockade protest that was set up in Montreal in spite of that new deal.

Finally, in light of a changing media landscape, Global TV has overhauled its streaming app to become the first mainstream Canadian broadcaster in Canada to offer all its current shows and live news programming for free while offering more channel options for cable subscribers. Mike Drolet explains why such adaptations are essential in the modern era of broadcasting and its consumers.

For more info, please go to http://www.globalnews.ca

description:
Our top story on Wednesday looks at what historic measures Prime Minister Justin Trudeau says will be undertaken to help Canadians forced to stay at home because of the coronavirus pandemic.

Eric Sorensen takes a look at how different regions of the country compare and contrast in the COVID-19 pandemic with Ontario and Quebec standing out, while Alberta and B.C. seem to be trending in the right direction. Meanwhile, Jeff Semple reports on contact tracing and how countries that have used this method have had the most success fighting the spread of COVID-19.

David Akin has new details on the Canadian government’s wage subsidy/Emergency Response Benefit. Also, Ross Lord takes a deeper look at the financial troubles the government of Newfoundland & Labrador has found itself in as it struggles to pay staff.

Jackson Proskow has the latest on the U.S. fight against the coronavirus as confirmed cases continue to rise.

Mike Armstrong delves into the face mask debate while Heather Yourex-West reports on clinical trials and potential treatments for COVID-19.

title: Global National: Feb. 12, 2022 | Police move in to clear Ambassador Bridge blockade
description:
The clearing has begun. Police are moving in to enforce the court order against protesters at the Ambassador Bridge blockade. They’ve disrupted North America’s busiest international crossing for six days now. A state of emergency is in effect in Ontario with demonstrations also underway at the Peace Bridge in Fort Erie. And in Ottawa, thousands gathered in the downtown core and at the National War Memorial. A counter-protest is picking up steam. Sean O’Shea is in Windsor, Ont. at the Ambassador Bridge where police have begun to move in. 
 
Day 16 of what the prime minister and police are calling an illegal occupation in our nation’s capital. All available officers are being deployed to enforce safety and to encourage protesters to leave, but the disruption continues. Crowds swelled in Ottawa’s downtown core again and as Abigail Bimman reports, the National War Memorial has become a flashpoint. 
 
With Alberta rapidly winding down its COVID-19 restrictions, Premier Jason Kenney says it’s not because of the ongoing blockade in Coutts, near the Alberta-Montana border crossing that’s disrupted traffic there for two weeks. The Canada Border Services Agency says services there are now temporarily suspended. Mercedes Stephenson has more. 
 
Fearing a Russian invasion is imminent, the U.S. is the latest country to tell its citizens to leave Ukraine.  Canada has already done so, but Global Affairs says nearly 800 registered Canadians are still there. Prime Minister Justin Trudeau offered support to Ukraine’s president in a phone call today, but as Jennifer Johnson reports, some are urging him to do more. 
 
Scientists are taking a giant step forward in spinal injury research, published this week in the journal Nature Medicine. As Mike Drolet shows us, Swiss-based researchers have developed a spinal implant that’s enabling a paraplegic to walk again. 

For more info, please go to https://globalnews.ca/national/program/global-national

title: Global National: March 22, 2020 | Cracking down to control the spread of COVID-19
description:
Governments are cracking down across Canada this weekend as more and more provinces are putting measures in place in an attempt to better control the spread of COVID-19.

Ross Lord reports on Nova Scotia declaring a state of emergency with strict new rules and penalties for those not practicing social distancing. Meanwhile, Mike Armstrong looks at what other provinces are doing – and not doing – to prevent people from ignoring social distancing and self-isolation guidelines.

Jeff Semple reports on the difficulty our health care workers face in the COVID-19 pandemic, as they face a critical shortage of life-saving supplies, while Amanda Jelowicki explains how funeral homes are helping grieving families lay loved ones to rest when social gatherings are meant to be limited.

As many of us experience what it’s like to be in self-isolation for the first time, Robin Gill has a message from a famous Canadian – former astronaut Chris Hadfield – about how to make the most of your time inside. To bring some levity to a difficult situation, Mike Drolet looks at the good deeds some Canadians are doing to support their communities during a tough time.

For more info, please go to https://globalnews.ca/news/6715159/coronavirus-canada-federal-emergency/

title: Global National: Feb. 10, 2020 | Coronavirus cases rise as quarantined cruise passengers cope
description:
Mike Le Couteur reports on how some people quarantined on a cruise ship due to the novel coronavirus are coping, as more confirmed cases are found on board. Plus, Crystal Goomansingh explains why the U.K. declared the virus an "imminent threat" to the public, and the new aggressive steps it's taking to stop the spread.

David Akin reports on Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's surprise visit to Canadian troops in Kuwait. Plus, Dawna Friesen looks at the ongoing protests across the country against the Coastal GasLink pipeline, and at the federal government announcing it will consult Indigenous groups about the Trans Mountain pipeline. 

Oscar history has been made with South Korean film 'Parasite' becoming the first non-English film to win the Academy Award for 'Best Picture.' Eric Sorensen explains the significance in an awards ceremony frequently criticized for lacking diversity.

Jackson Proskow reports on how Democrats are favouring Pete Buttigieg over Joe Biden ahead of the New Hampshire primary. Also, Dawna Friesen has the details on who's just been charged in the massive hack that hit Equifax in 2017. Plus, how did the personal information of 6.5 million Israeli voters get exposed?

description:

Also, Morganne Campbell  has the details on a Global News investigation on staff training and use of personal protective equipment at care homes.

Mike Le Couteur reports on how much the emergency wage subsidy bill will help employers to re-hire workers laid off amid the COVID-19 pandemic, while Robin Gill reports on the current caseload of COVID-19 sweeping Canada, and the pledge by Alberta's premier to send a surplus of PPE to provinces in critical need.

Jennifer Johnson reports on a grim new milestone as the U.S. surpasses Italy for the most COVID-19 deaths.  

Finally, Redmond Shannon on the growing cases of COVID-19 in developing nations, and how third world countries are struggling to prepare for the pandemic.

description:

title: 13 year old Botlhale Boikanyo shines as youngest SAMA nominee
description:
The 21st Annual South African Music Awards (SAMA) nominations received a pop of youthful energy with child star, Botlhale Boikanyo (13), being the youngest artist to receive a nomination with her album.
Botlhale Boikanyo is no stranger to success as she competes with South Africa's best of all ages with an already impressive collection of titles under her belt. 
Her rocket to fame launched as the winner of SA's Got Talent in 2012, paving the way for her two 2013 South African Traditional Music Awards nominations for Best Praise Singer and Best Poet, and winning the award for Best Praise Singer. She joins us in studio to tell us more about her SAMA nomination.

title: ARNOLD CLAVIO NAGSALITA NA? | NETIZENS IBOBOYCOTT ANG GMA-7 KAPAG HINDI SISIBAKIN SI CLAVIO!
description:
Isang dating host sa GMA 7 ang hinimok si Arnold Clavio na magsalita na tungkol sa rebelasyon ng dating Overseas Filipino Worker  at ngayo’y radio host na si Sarah Balabagan matatandaan na sinabi ni Balabagan na nagkaroon sila ng relasyon ni Clavio 22 taon na ang nakararaan at nagbunga pa ito ng isang sanggol.

#sarahbalabagan #arnoldclavio #boycottgma

title: 2023 State of the Nation Address
description:
President Cyril Ramaphosa delivers the 2023 state of the nation address. 
This year's state of the nation address comes on the back of a myriad of challenges facing the nation.
The country is in the grips of a power crisis that's punctuated by rolling blackouts.
Poorer households are struggling to make ends meet amid higher interest rates, the rising cost of living and rampant unemployment.

For more news, visit sabcnews.com and #SABCNews on all Social Media platforms.

title: Senzo Meyiwa Murder Trial | 13 June 2022
description:
The murder trial of former Orlando Pirates and Bafana Bafana goalkeeper Senzo Meyiwa continues in the High Court in Pretoria .

For more news, visit sabcnews.com and also #SABCNews on all Social Media platforms.

title: President Cyril Ramaphosa Nation address on COVID-19 responses
description:
President Cyril Ramaphosa addresses the nation amid rise in COVID-19 infections. In a bid to curb the transmissions, His Excellency the president is expected to announce stricter lockdown restrictions. 

For more news, visit sabcnews.com and also #SABCNews #Coronavirus #COVID19News on Social Media.

title: Thabo Bester Saga | Confession by a G4S CCTV technician on the day of escape: Chriselda Lewis
description:
An investigating officer in the Thabo Bester escape saga has told the Bloemfontein Magistrate's Court that former G4S CCTV installer, and accused number three, Teboho Lipholo, called police to confess about his role, and that of other staff, in the jailbreak. Chriselda Lewis has the latest.

For more news, visit sabcnews.com and #SABCNews on all Social Media platforms.

title: Gold Mafia I Zimbabwean nationals picket outside Pastor Uebert Angel's church in Boksburg
description:
A group of Zimbabwean nationals are picketing outside Pastor Uebert Angel's church in Boksburg, Ekurhuleni. The Pastor has been implicated in a gold smuggling scandal. 
Some South African banks were also embroiled.

Khayelihle Khumalo joins us from Boksburg.

For more news, visit sabcnews.com and #SABCNews on all Social Media platforms.

title: President Cyril Ramaphosa's address to the nation on COVID-19 response
description:
President Cyril Ramaphosa addresses the nation amid rise in COVID-19 infections.  

For more news, visit sabcnews.com and also #SABCNews #Coronavirus #COVID19News on Social Media.

title: NAKAKAMANGHANG PROYEKTO NI PRES.DUTERTE BINUKSAN NA | SORSOGON COASTAL ROAD | DILAWAN SUPALPAL!
description:
Bukas na sa publiko ang isa sa mga “grandest” project sa Bicol region sa ilalim ng programang “Build, Build, Build” ng administrasyong duterte..Sabi ni DPWH Secretary Mark Villar, binuksan na ang Sorsogon City Coastal Road, na may apat na lane at haba na 5.52 kilometro mula Sorsogon baywalk hanggang Barangay Balogo.

description: For more news, visit sabcnews.com and also #SABCNews, #Coronavirus, #COVID19, COVID-19 News on Social Media.

title: Chaos erupts at OR Tambo International Airport
description:
Chaos erupted at OR Tambo International Airport on Wednesday morning when over 50 passengers were left stranded. The cause was an overbooked Ethiopian Airways flight to Addis Abba which left South African skies in the early hours of Wednesday morning. Some desperate passengers trying to get on the flight, allegedly jumped over a counter at the airlines check-in point.


For more news, visit sabcnews.com and also #SABCNews #Coronavirus #COVID19News #Covid-19Vaccination #Vaccine on Social Media.

title: DILAWAN SUMAKIT ANG MATA SA GANDA NG MANILA BAY | DDS BLOGGERS TINUSTA ANG OPOSISYON!
description:
Sa naging rehabilitasyon ng manila bay ay umani nga ito ng maraming pagbatikos mula sa mga oposisyon at mga dilawan, dahil nagsasayang lang umano ang gobyerno ng pera imbes na pambili ng pagkain sa mga mahihirap ngayong nahaharap ang bansa sa matinding krisis bunsod ng pandemya, malaki nga ang naging pagbabago ng manila bay simula ng maupo ang pangulong duterte, mula sa tambak na basura at nakakasulasok na amoy ay mala boracay na ang ganda ng manila bay ngayon , sa kabila ng batikos ay mas marami naman ang humanga sa adhikain at agarang aksiyon ng gobyrno na maibalik ang dating ganda ng naturang lugar.

#manilabayupdates #dutertenews #wowmanilabay

title: How Does the Internet Work? - Glad You Asked S1
description:
For most of us, the internet is virtual, made of Instagram posts, emails and YouTube videos. And, access to the vital utility isn’t guaranteed across the world. Glad You Asked host Cleo Abram wants to know: What is the internet actually made of? And, how does it work? Answering that question involves discovering how internet cables are laid in the sea, if 5G is really the future, and how balloons in the stratosphere are helping people connect.

Key Sources: 
Submarine Cable Map - https://www.submarinecablemap.com/ 

Code, Charles Petzold - https://www.amazon.com/Code-Language-Computer-Hardware-Software/dp/0735611319 

Tubes, by Andrew Blum - https://www.amazon.com/Tubes-Journey-Internet-Andrew-Blum/dp/0061994952

Internet Cable Protection Committee Report - https://cdn.arstechnica.net/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/ICPC-sharks.pdf

title: Why Do We Cry? - Glad You Asked S1
description:
Glad You Asked host Joss Fong has been fascinated by crying her entire life. She’s even kept a spreadsheet of every time she cries to figure out what patterns lie in the triggers. This episode explores how crying evolved in humans and what it tells us about ourselves.

Here are some of the videos Joss had the other hosts watch:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uaWA2GbcnJU

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=La3b_1F8h_4

Thai ad “Unsung Hero”: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uaWA2GbcnJU
Why Only Humans Weep by Ad Vingerhoets https://www.amazon.com/dp/B00B9WPN00/ref=dp-kindle-redirect?_encoding=UTF8&btkr=1

title: Why Spend Money in Video Games? - Glad You Asked S1
description:
Glad You Asked host Alex Clark has been a gamer for most of his life. And in all his years of playing, he's spent a great deal of money buying and selling virtual items in video games. He’s not alone -- billions of dollars are spent inside the virtual economies of video games. So why spend money on a virtual good? And how did they become so valuable? 

Key sources: 
CS:GO 'Dragon Lore' AWP skin sells for more than $61,000 https://www.pcgamer.com/csgo-dragon-lore-awp-skin-sells-for-more-than-61000/

Bank Failure in Second Life Leads to Calls for Regulation https://www.wired.com/2007/08/bank-failure-in-second-life-leads-to-calls-for-regulation/

Meet The Man Who Just Made A Half Million From The Sale Of Virtual Property https://www.forbes.com/sites/oliverchiang/2010/11/13/meet-the-man-who-just-made-a-cool-half-million-from-the-sale-of-virtual-property/#640c50b721cd

title: How Do I Pay for College?
description:
Higher education is likely the biggest purchase you’ve made in your life thus far, but it doesn’t have to be as scary as it feels right now. In this episode, we’re going over everything you need to know about paying for school and the different options available, including FAFSA, scholarships, grants, work-study, and loans. Take it from Michelle Obama herself, go to the financial aid office and get to know the staff — they’re there to help you understand this process. In this episode, you’ll hear from Emmanuel Moses, Assistant Director of College Guidance and Transition at The Opportunity Network, Wes Moore, CEO of Robin Hood, Eric Waldo, Executive Director of Reach Higher, and Michelle Obama. 

Check out the full learning playlist, A Student’s Guide to Your First Year of College, for all the tips and tricks you need to succeed freshman year, featuring advice from experts, upperclassmen, and Michelle Obama. A Student’s Guide to Your First Year of College was produced by NowThis and YouTube Originals in partnership with Reach Higher.
